articles.title: How Stacey Solomon decluttered our homes back from the brink
articles.summary: Three families share the realisations that enabled them to declutter and transform their homes and lives.
articles.content:
How Stacey Solomon decluttered our homes back from the brink

3 hours ago Share Save Emily Holt BBC News Share Save

BBC Sheeny and Sohan were delighted by the transformation done by Stacey's team

Has your home become messy without you even realising? Wanting the next best thing, holding on to things for sentimental reasons or just a lack of time to sort through your space can all mean you end up with too much stuff. Sort Your Life Out hosted by Stacey Solomon helps people declutter and shows the transformational impact that getting rid of things you don't need can have on your family and home. If you're struggling to clear items in your home, here are how three different families who took part in the series managed it and the one key realisation that helped them do it. For more practical advice on how to clear your space click here

I don't want my kids to buy things to feel good

Sheeny Aphabhai-Heer lives with her partner Sohan, and children Milly, 22, Leila, 9 and Ethan, 4. The house is piled high with clothes, shoes, suitcases and kitchen equipment, meaning they have to eat separately at mealtimes as there isn't enough space to sit together. This lack of space also means it is a struggle for daughter Milly to work from home. Sheeny had Milly when she was 17 and in a difficult marriage. She managed to leave the marriage and buy her own house as a single mum. "My mum's a superwoman, she's been through a lot in her life and she came out of there knowing she had to do her best and provide for me," says daughter Milly. When Sheeny started to earn money, she wanted things that she could be proud of, and the purchases increased from there. She says she often spends nights scrolling through shopping apps like Vinted, but wants to break this cycle for her kids. "I noticed a growing trend in Milly and Leila. When something new is happening, they want a new outfit. "That's my habit. Buying something new to feel good cannot be the legacy I give to my children." By letting go of her clothes and shoes, Sheeny wants to be an example to her kids, showing that she can change and break the constant cycle of shopping. It was this realisation which enabled the Aphabhai-Heers' to get rid of just over 40% of their belongings. This meant Stacey Solomon and her team were able to transform the dining room with added desk space for Milly to work, and there was also enough space for the family to be able to eat meals together again. "It's literally changed the dynamic of our family," says Sheeny.

Giving away my wife's things didn't mean we'd forget her

Craig (centre) and his two daughters Merywen and Wren with the Sort Your Life Out team.

Craig Bufton is a single dad to two daughters, Wren, 4 and Merywen, 6. After Craig's wife Lois gave birth to Wren she was constantly exhausted. Eventually she was diagnosed with cancer, dying just eight months later. As a widowed father, the clutter built up as Craig focused on raising the girls as a single parent. He struggled to tackle the house as he couldn't face dealing with sentimental items tied to Lois, such as storybooks she wrote for the children, photos and a hoard of Christmas items she loved. "There's just so much sentimental stuff and so many of our plans that aren't going to happen anymore." His office also got out of control as paperwork piled up, and the living room ended up covered in toys and different hobby equipment. "It took me a really long time to realise I was buying stuff to just get the dopamine hit out of it. So much of the stuff I have is 'oh this will make me happy' and it did for about 20 minutes." Craig eventually decided to take action to create a house that was a special and relaxing place for his two daughters to grow up. The key to doing this was to let go of sentimental items tied to Lois. Stacey and her team encouraged Craig to focus on the items he was keeping because they had real meaning and memories, and not the things he was letting go of. One example is Lois' Christmas baubles, which Craig disliked. Rather than keep them all anyway, he held onto specific baubles for their daughters. Decluttering like this enabled him to downsize his office, creating a space for him to work downstairs instead. And in the place of his office they created a special reading room for the girls. This space meant Lois' love for stories and writing was kept alive, with her books on full display. The family now has the space to eat together, and a room where Craig can read Lois' storybooks to their children. Since this episode aired, Craig has found a new partner and has moved house with his daughters.

Time with my kids was more important than crafting

The Clarke family consists of mum Sarah, dad Jon, and children Timeon, 14, Owen, 9 and Caitlin, 11. Sarah is an avid crafts enthusiast, with an abundance of yarn, beads and other art materials in her home. Currently, her younger children, Owen and Caitlin, share a room, and Sarah's crafts mean that a room that could be used for one of them can't be. The clutter of books, board games and toys in their house means making space for the family to sit and chat together is incredibly hard. Both Sarah and Jon are deaf, and mum Sarah finds making crafts a way for her to destress from everyday life. "I like making things, it makes me feel good, creativity is therapeutic, it makes me calmer and relaxed." "My mum holds everything dear to her heart" says Timeon. The team found an array of unfinished craft items all over the house, including an unfinished crochet bag from 15 years ago. Sarah feels a lot of guilt because she knew the time with her children was being impacted. "I do lots with them but it doesn't stop the guilt being real." Having the team come in helped her realise she had to prioritise time with the kids over her crafts. "Children grow up faster, and my projects will always be there." It was this realisation which helped her to let go of half of their items. Owen and Caitlin were able to have their own rooms, as Sarah's crafts were compacted into the living room in a large cupboard. After decluttering, Jon says there has been a massive improvement in their family life and now they are able to spend quality time together to sit and chat.

articles.personality_title: How Stacey Solomon helped families clear clutter and improve their homes
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many families find their homes becoming messy without realizing it. Keeping too many things can make daily life harder and cause stress. Stacey Solomon’s show, Sort Your Life Out, helps families declutter and create better living spaces.

**What happened** – Three families took part in the show and shared what helped them let go of extra items. Sheeny’s family cleared over 40% of their belongings, making space for meals and work. Craig, a widower, sorted through sentimental items, keeping only those with real meaning, and made a cozy reading room for his daughters. Sarah’s family reduced craft supplies so her children could each have their own room and spend more time together.

**Impact** – Decluttering changed how these families live. Sheeny’s home became a place where everyone can eat and work together. Craig’s family honored memories while creating room for new ones. Sarah’s family found more time to connect. These changes improved family relationships and made homes feel calmer and more organized.

**What's next step** – The show will continue to help more families find ways to clear clutter and improve their homes. Families watching can learn practical tips to make space for what really matters.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Decluttering with care helped these families create more space, stronger connections, and happier homes.

articles.personality_title_es: Cómo Stacey Solomon ayudó a familias a ordenar y mejorar sus hogares
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Muchas familias notan que sus casas se vuelven desordenadas sin darse cuenta. Guardar demasiadas cosas puede dificultar la vida diaria y causar estrés. El programa Sort Your Life Out, presentado por Stacey Solomon, ayuda a las familias a ordenar y crear mejores espacios para vivir.

**Qué pasó** – Tres familias participaron en el programa y compartieron qué les ayudó a deshacerse de objetos innecesarios. La familia de Sheeny eliminó más del 40 % de sus pertenencias, ganando espacio para comer y trabajar. Craig, viudo, organizó los objetos sentimentales, quedándose solo con los que tenían verdadero significado, y creó una sala de lectura para sus hijas. La familia de Sarah redujo sus materiales de manualidades para que sus hijos tuvieran habitaciones propias y pasaran más tiempo juntos.

**Impacto** – Ordenar cambió la forma en que estas familias viven. El hogar de Sheeny se convirtió en un lugar donde todos pueden comer y trabajar juntos. La familia de Craig mantuvo recuerdos importantes mientras hacía espacio para nuevos momentos. La familia de Sarah encontró más tiempo para conectarse. Estos cambios mejoraron las relaciones familiares y hicieron que las casas fueran más tranquilas y organizadas.

**Próximo paso** – El programa seguirá ayudando a más familias a ordenar y mejorar sus hogares. Las familias que lo ven pueden aprender consejos prácticos para hacer espacio para lo que realmente importa.

**Resumen en una frase** – Ordenar con cuidado ayudó a estas familias a crear más espacio, conexiones más fuertes y hogares más felices.

articles.title: The European Commissioner for Agriculture will travel to Bulgaria to get acquainted on the spot with the challenges facing farmers
articles.summary: Christoph Hansen said that 65 percent of the funds in the next multiannual budget of the EU until 2034 are still not allocated for specific projects.
articles.content:
Christoph Hansen said that 65 percent of the funds in the next multiannual budget of the EU until 2034 are still not allocated for specific projects.

BRUSSELS/STRASBOURG – The European Commissioner for Agriculture and Rural Development Christophe Hansen will be in Bulgaria this week for meetings with government representatives and agricultural organizations. In an interview with BTA, the commissioner explained that he would like to meet with Bulgarian farmers to better understand the challenges they face.

According to him, Bulgaria will have significant funds in the next multiannual EU budget until 2034, with 65 percent of the funds still not allocated to specific projects. There are sufficient funds for farmers, he said. The commissioner noted that 6.2 billion euros are allocated for Bulgaria under the future Common Agricultural Policy, and 19.5 billion euros under the partnership plans.

Hansen pointed out that direct payments to farmers and environmental protection schemes are maintained in the new multiannual common budget, as well as support for investments in agriculture. We have preserved 80 percent of the previous Common Agricultural Policy – 300 billion euros, the European Commissioner explained.

He indicated that the war in Ukraine has affected the European market, but measures have been introduced to safeguard the interests of European farmers and livestock breeders. Hansen clarified that Ukraine has until 2028 to implement changes to align its agricultural conditions with European ones; otherwise, it will face a halt in imports to the EU market. According to him, the measures taken in the meantime by the European side have led to a fivefold reduction in the import of goods, which has impacted the EU market.

The European Commissioner noted that the EC’s proposals to reduce bureaucracy in agriculture could save European producers 1.6 billion euros annually. I hope the European Parliament will vote on its position this week, he said, expressing hope that the subsequent trilateral negotiations in European institutions will conclude quickly.

We want EU funds to reach the accounts of those who cultivate the land and produce, which has not always been the case so far, Hansen pointed out. We propose to improve the link between the provided aid and production, he explained. According to him, the new Common Agricultural Policy will be much simplified and will facilitate checks for abuses. I am convinced that this will reduce the risk of misuse of European funds, summarized Commissioner Hansen. (October 6)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on significant EU budget allocations and policy measures aimed at supporting farmers and rural development in Bulgaria and the EU, which has broad societal impact by promoting agricultural sustainability and economic stability. The focus on reducing bureaucracy and safeguarding funds for producers adds substance and potential positive real-world impact. However, the article is somewhat general and focused on policy announcements rather than a concrete breakthrough or event, so the sentiment score is moderate.
articles.personality_title: EU Agriculture Commissioner visits Bulgaria to support farmers and simplify funding
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) has a big budget to support farmers and rural areas until 2034. However, many of these funds are not yet assigned to specific projects. The EU wants to make sure money reaches the farmers and helps them grow food and protect the environment.

**What happened** – Christoph Hansen, the European Commissioner for Agriculture, traveled to Bulgaria to meet with government officials and farmers. He wants to understand the challenges Bulgarian farmers face. Bulgaria will receive large amounts of EU money—6.2 billion euros from the Common Agricultural Policy and 19.5 billion euros through partnership plans.

**Impact** – This visit shows the EU’s commitment to helping farmers by simplifying rules and protecting funds from misuse. Hansen said that keeping direct payments and environmental support will help farmers invest in their land. The plan also includes reducing paperwork, which could save farmers 1.6 billion euros every year. These efforts aim to make farming easier and more secure, especially after challenges like the war in Ukraine affected markets.

**What's next step** – The European Parliament will soon vote on proposals to reduce bureaucracy in farming. After that, talks between EU institutions will work to finalize the new rules quickly. The goal is to ensure the money reaches farmers faster and supports real farming activities.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU is working to deliver billions in funds directly to farmers while cutting red tape to help agriculture grow stronger and more sustainable in Bulgaria and beyond.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le commissaire européen à l’agriculture visite la Bulgarie pour soutenir les agriculteurs et simplifier les financements
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne (UE) dispose d’un important budget pour soutenir les agriculteurs et les zones rurales jusqu’en 2034. Cependant, une grande partie de ces fonds n’est pas encore attribuée à des projets précis. L’UE veut s’assurer que l’argent parvienne aux agriculteurs pour les aider à produire de la nourriture et protéger l’environnement.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Christoph Hansen, le commissaire européen à l’agriculture, s’est rendu en Bulgarie pour rencontrer des responsables gouvernementaux et des agriculteurs. Il souhaite mieux comprendre les défis auxquels les agriculteurs bulgares font face. La Bulgarie recevra d’importantes sommes d’argent de l’UE : 6,2 milliards d’euros dans le cadre de la Politique agricole commune et 19,5 milliards d’euros via des plans de partenariat.

**Impact** – Cette visite montre l’engagement de l’UE à aider les agriculteurs en simplifiant les règles et en protégeant les fonds contre les abus. Hansen a expliqué que le maintien des paiements directs et du soutien environnemental aidera les agriculteurs à investir dans leurs terres. Le plan prévoit aussi de réduire la paperasse, ce qui pourrait faire économiser 1,6 milliard d’euros par an aux agriculteurs. Ces mesures visent à faciliter et sécuriser l’agriculture, surtout après que la guerre en Ukraine a perturbé les marchés.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Parlement européen doit bientôt voter sur les propositions visant à réduire la bureaucratie dans l’agriculture. Ensuite, des négociations entre institutions européennes travailleront à finaliser rapidement les nouvelles règles. L’objectif est que l’argent parvienne plus vite aux agriculteurs et soutienne de réelles activités agricoles.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’UE travaille à verser directement des milliards aux agriculteurs tout en réduisant les formalités pour renforcer l’agriculture en Bulgarie et dans toute l’Europe.
articles.personality_title_es: El comisario europeo de agricultura visita Bulgaria para apoyar a los agricultores y simplificar los fondos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea (UE) tiene un gran presupuesto para apoyar a los agricultores y las zonas rurales hasta 2034. Sin embargo, muchos de estos fondos aún no están asignados a proyectos específicos. La UE quiere asegurarse de que el dinero llegue a los agricultores para ayudarlos a producir alimentos y proteger el medio ambiente.

**Qué pasó** – Christoph Hansen, el comisario europeo de agricultura, viajó a Bulgaria para reunirse con funcionarios del gobierno y agricultores. Quiere entender los desafíos que enfrentan los agricultores búlgaros. Bulgaria recibirá grandes cantidades de dinero de la UE: 6.2 mil millones de euros del Programa Común Agrícola y 19.5 mil millones a través de planes de asociación.

**Impacto** – Esta visita muestra el compromiso de la UE para ayudar a los agricultores simplificando las reglas y protegiendo los fondos contra el mal uso. Hansen dijo que mantener los pagos directos y el apoyo ambiental ayudará a los agricultores a invertir en sus tierras. También planean reducir la burocracia, lo que podría ahorrar a los agricultores 1.6 mil millones de euros cada año. Estos esfuerzos buscan facilitar y asegurar la agricultura, especialmente tras los problemas causados por la guerra en Ucrania.

**Próximo paso** – El Parlamento Europeo votará pronto las propuestas para reducir la burocracia en la agricultura. Después, las instituciones de la UE negociarán para finalizar las nuevas reglas rápidamente. El objetivo es que el dinero llegue más rápido a los agricultores y apoye actividades agrícolas reales.

**Una frase para recordar** – La UE trabaja para entregar miles de millones directamente a los agricultores mientras reduce trámites para fortalecer la agricultura en Bulgaria y en toda Europa.
